fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In lines 78-80a of the "Dream of the Rood":
fr:mainmatter.fr:blockquote: Nu ðu miht gehyran, hæleð min se leofa, þæt ic bealuwara weorc gebiden hæbbe, sarra sorga.
Now you may hear, my dear warrior, that I have endured the works of wicked men, grevious sorrows.
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Here, the neuter acc. weorc is roughly Mdn.E. "work", and bealuwara (perhaps the gen. pl. of an unrecorded bealuware, a compound of bealu, "baleful", "wicked", and wara, "inhabitant") has been translated variously as "miscreants", "wicked men". Bosworth Toller's has "baleful inhabitants", "criminals". But apparently this bit has caused philologists a lot of trouble.

Interestingly, it's tempting to compare also "Balrog", which in Sindarin comes from BAL ("power") + raug/rog ("demon"), but has echoes of bealu-wearg ("outlaw", "wolf") or bealu-broga ("monster", "terror").
